questions.text: A patient on therapy with a certain drug, developed a sharply demarcated, erythematous lesion on the 5th day which progressed to form large, hemorrhagic bulla with eventual necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation as seen in the image given below. The drug most likely  causing this condition is _____________
questions.solution:
The given history of a sharply demarcated erythematous lesion on the 5th day of initiating of a certain drug, which progressed to form large, hemorrhagic bullae with necrosis & slow healing eschar formation (above image) is strongly suggestive of Warfarin-induced Skin Necrosis.

  • Skin Necrosis is a very rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy. 
  • The lesions typically begin as sharply demarcated, erythematous indurations or purpura. This may progress to form large, hemorrhagic bullae with eventual necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation. 
  • Usual sites involved are breasts, thighs, buttocks, and toes.
  • Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk. 
  • The pathogenesis involves a sudden drop in plasma levels of Protein C & S (Vit K dependent anticoagulant proteins) by Warfarin. This sudden drop promotes hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. 
  • Treatment involves discontinuation of warfarin and reversal with vitamin K, if necessary. An alternative anticoagulant, such as heparin or LMWH, should be given in patients with thrombosis. Protein C concentrate can be given to protein C–deficient patients which may help faster healing of the skin lesions.
  • Skin grafting may be necessary.

questions.text: Large doses of iodide given to patient with hyperplastic goitre causing hyperthyroidism is called as_______
questions.solution:
Jod–Basedow thyrotoxicosis:

Large doses of iodide given to a patient with a hyperplastic endemic goitre that is iodine avid may produce temporary hyperthyroidism and very occasionally persistent hyperthyroidism.

Other options

Option A- Wolff chaikoff effect:

  • Hypothyroidism caused by ingestion of large amount of iodine (thyroid constipation).

Option C- Secondary thyrotoxicosis:

  • The goitre is nodular. The onset is insidious and may present with cardiac failure or atrial ﬁbrillation. The hyperthyroidism is not severe and very infrequently is associated with eye signs.

Option D- Thyrotoxicosis facticia:

  • Hyperthyroidism may be induced by taking thyroxine, but only if the dosage exceeds the normal requirements of 0.15–0.25 mg per day.

questions.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with infertility. During the procedure, the surgeon notices powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera is seen in pelvic endometriosis. 

Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/gunshot appearance seen on the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or can be small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Other subtle appearances of endometriosis are red flame-shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow-brown patches, white peritoneal plaques or scarring, peritoneal defects (known as Allen Masters Syndrome), and subovarian adhesions. These lesions are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish-brown fluid which has prostaglandin responsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: Chocolate cyst (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

Powder burn appearance:

questions.text: You observed that the arms of an infant extend spontaneously when the senior resident tries to elicit the following reflex by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. All the following options regarding this reflex is true except _______

choices.text: This reflex is  a prerequisite to walking
This reflex starts to appear by 7–8 months of age
This reflex disappears by 18 months of postnatal period

questions.solution:
The reflex being elicited in the given scenario is the Parachute reflex and this reflex remains throughout life.

  • The Parachute reflex is a primitive reflex that occurs at 7-8 months of age and it is fully developed by 10-11 months of the postnatal period.
  • It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall.
  • This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident and eFAST was performed on him. Which among the following statements is true regarding eFAST?

choices.text: It detects free fluid in the abdomen or pericardium
It helps in assessment of retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
eFAST/extended FAST helps in detecting free fluid in the abdomen and pericardium. 

Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) aims to identify intra-abdominal free fluid (assumed to be hemoperitoneum in the context of trauma) allowing for an immediate transfer to OT for surgery or for CT for further workup.  FAST (Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma) is the best diagnostic modality for a hemodynamically unstable patient with blunt trauma abdomen.

The standard order of evaluation is:

  • Pericardial (subxiphoid)
  • Right flank (hepatorenal view or "Morison's pouch")
  • Left flank (perisplenic view)
  • Pelvic (retrovesical views)

eFAST/ Extended FAST assesses pleural (pneumothorax and hemothorax evaluations), pericardial region, right flank, left flank and pelvic region. It is accurate in detecting > 100 ml of free blood. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury is difficult to diagnose. It is also unreliable in excluding injury in penetrating trauma. It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes with complaints of patchy hair loss. Dermoscopy of the scalp skin was normal. On histology, numerous empty canals were seen. Clefts were noticed in the hair matrix and the follicular epithelium is separated from the connec­tive tissue sheath. Intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical vignette, the most likely diagnosis is trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania is a psychiatric disorder characterized by com­pulsive hair pulling. There is increased tension prior to the hair pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair-pulling.

It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.

Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, perianal region.

Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages. Numerous empty canals, severely damaged follicles, clefts in the hair matrix are also seen. The follicular epithelium separates from the connec­tive tissue sheath.

Trichotillomania is given in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata- characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. Follicular orifices may appear as yellow dots on dermoscopy.

Option B: Tinea capitis - the appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans. 

Option D: Traction alopecia - caused by hairstyles that impose a sus­tained pull on the hair roots. The pattern of the hair loss will reflect the dis­tribution of the traction.

The images below show Alopecia areata and Tinea capitis respectively.

Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone.

It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.

Osteomyelitis of the frontal bone results from acute infection of frontal sinus either directly or through the venous spread. It can also follow trauma or surgery of the frontal sinus in the presence of acute infection. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as soft doughy swelling (Pott’s puffy tumour), or internally as an extradural abscess.

Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision.

questions.text: Cornea is obtained from a brain dead patient for transplantation. What is the maximum duration for which a donor cornea can be stored by organ culture methods?
questions.solution:
The cornea can be preserved for a maximum of 30 days by organ culture methods using modified Eagle’s media.

Related Pearl: Corneal Preservation

Corneal preservation – They can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank by various preservation techniques for varying intervals.

  • Short-term preservation
    • In a moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium (MK medium)
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C
    • Cornea to be used within 48 to 72 hours (maximum 96 hours)
  • Intermediate– term preservation
    • In medium containing chondroitin sulfate
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C for 7 to 14 days
    • Or maintained at 37°C by organ culture methods
    • Using modified Eagle's medium extends this to 30 days
  • Long-term preservation
    • By cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or in glycerol
    • Is up to 1 year
    • Loss of transparency of the tissue is a disadvantage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a demographic process?
questions.solution:
Demographic processes include fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following is detected in supravital stain as "golf ball" inclusions?
questions.solution:
Hb H inclusions in red cells are described as "golf ball" inclusions in the supravital stain. It is composed of tetramers of β chains.

Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. The decreased alpha-chain production leads to a relative excess of beta-chains which lead to the formation of HbH, the tetramers of the beta-chains

Note the "Golf-ball" appearance of the red cells (cells with HbH inclusion bodies) with supervital stain after prolonged incubation. They are diagnostic of alpha-thalassaemias.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman gave birth to a child with the features of depressed nasal bridge and dilated cardiomyopathy..  The child also had brittle bones and X-rays revealed stippled epiphyses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in causing this teratogenic condition?
questions.solution:
Depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose), dilated cardiomyopathy along with stippling of bone epiphyses points to Fetal warfarin syndrome or Warfarin embryopathy. 

Features:

  • Repeated abortions
  • CNS abnormalities
  • Depressed nasal bridge/ absent nasal bone/ saddle nose at birth
  • Bleeding diathesis at birth 
  • Growth retardation - hypoplasia of nose, eye sockets, and long bones with stippling of epiphyses. 

Anticoagulation in pregnancy:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG do not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If delivery supervenes while the anticoagulant is still effective, and extensive bleeding is encountered, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. 

The American College of Chest Physicians Guidelines for anticoagulation of pregnant women:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week of gestation. 
  • This is then replaced by a warfarin tablet 3 mg daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks in patients with a high risk of thrombosis.
  • Thereafter it is replaced by heparin which is discontinued 6 hours just before delivery
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • UFH (unfractionated heparin), LMWH, and Warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breastfeeding.

Stereocilia are found in epididymis.

The epithelial lining of the epididymal tubule contains principal, basal, apical and clear cells. Principal cells are tall columnar cells with basally located, oval nuclei. They bear long stereocilia and function to resorb testicular fluid.

Other options:

Fallopian tubes are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium.

Testis & ovary are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium – germinal epithelium.

Note:

Human spermatozoa acquire motility as they migrate through epididymis.

Human spermatozoa undergo capacitation in female reproductive tract.

questions.text: The principal neurotransmitter in Type I (Glomus) cells of the carotid body is:
questions.solution:
Dopamine is the principal neurotransmitter in type I (glomus) cells of the carotid and aortic bodies.

Carotid and aortic bodies contain Type I cells/Glomus cells and Type II cells. Like adrenal chromaffin cells, they contain dense-core granules containing catecholamines. They are excited in a hypoxic state upon and their principle transmitter is dopamine which stimulates the efferent nerve endings via D2 receptors.
